Description: East Greek terracotta figure vase (plastic vase), in the form of a dove or pigeon, body rests on two long feet and tail. Traces of red paint on top of rim. From two-piece mould. Fairly fine light red-brown/beige micaceous clay with some lime inclusions. Broken at neck and head lost, tail damaged.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Close parallels from Naukratis (Boston, Museum of Fine Arts RES.87.265; Higgins 1970, no.100, GR 1886,0401.1357), unprovenanced (Higgins 1970, no.101, GR 1951,0731.2) and Centuripe (Higgins 1970, no.102, 1863,0728.429), all dated late 6th century BC and are likely of the same fabric. The fabric, parallels and style are consistent with what was previously assigned to Rhodes, though another Ionian origin cannot be excluded and this is more similar to that found at Miletus. Other parallels from Thera (Maximova 1927, 95 fig.9:1), Lindos, Ialysus and Bassae are sited by Higgins (1954, 59). Parallel from Kamiros (Jacopi 1929, fig. 106). Jacopi, G. 1929. Esplorazione archeologica di Camiro I. Clara Rhodos III. Maximova, M. I. 1927. ‘Les vases plastiques dans l’antiquité’. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.019) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4577 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
